statement.p: Now, since we want T_2(x) and \cos(x) to have the same height at x=0, set T_2(0)=f(0).
This implies b_0={}.
Since we want T_2(x) and \cos(x) to have the same slope at x=0, set T_2'(0)=f'(0).

statement.p: Throughout our work in Section, we have focused on approximating the function f(x) = e^x. In this exercise, we change the function of interest to f(x) = \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{4}x^2 - 2x - 1, and consider the linear and quadratic approximations to f near a = 0.

statement.p: In this exercise, we extend our work in Exercise. We continue to consider the function f(x) = \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{4}x^2 - 2x - 1, but now build the cubic (degree 3) approximation to f near a = 0.

li.p: Let T_3(x) = k_0 + k_1x + k_2x^2 + k_3x^3 and determine T_3'(x), T_3''(x), and T_3'''(x). In addition, determine f'''(x). Record your results below, along with the values of each of these functions at a = 0.
Use your work in above to find the formula for T_3(x) that satisfies T_3(0) = f(0), T_3'(0) = f'(0), T_3''(0) = f''(0), and T_3'''(0) = f'''(0).
Plot f(x), T_1(x), T_2(x), and T_3(x) on the same axes, centered at a = 0. What do you notice?
What do you expect the degree 4 approximation to f(x), T_4(x) to be? Why?
What do you expect will happen if we find the degree 6 approximation to any function f(x) that is itself a degree 6 polynomial?
T_3(x) = f(x) so T_3(x) is identical to the original function.
That the degree 6 approximation will be the original polynomial function itself.

We see that T_3(0) = f(0) implies k_0 = -1; T_3'(0) = f'(0) implies k_1 = -1; T_3''(0) = f''(0) tells us 2k_2 = \frac{1}{2}, so k_2 = \frac{1}{4}; and T_3'''(0) = f'''(0) shows that 6k_3 = 2, so k_3 = \frac{1}{3}. Thus T_3(x) = \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{4}x^2 - 2x - 1.
We notice that T_3(x) = f(x) so T_3(x) perfectly approximates f(x) for every value of x.
We expect that T_4(x) = T_3(x) = f(x) because there's no better polynomial approximation to f(x) than T_3(x).
If we find the degree 6 approximation to any function f(x) that is itself a degree 6 polynomial, we expect that the degree 6 approximation will be the original polynomial function itself.
